qas.question: What is the general opinion of Whitehead in most philosophical schools?

answers.text: Whitehead has not been recognized as particularly influential within the most dominant philosophical schools

qas.question: what is an example of Whitehead's ideas being counter-intuitive?

answers.text: his assertion that matter is an abstraction

qas.question: What is a common opinion of metaphysics?

answers.text: perception of metaphysics itself as passé

qas.question: Why do some people believe Whitehead's writings may have restricted his influence?

answers.text: the sheer difficulty and density of his prose

plausible_answers.text: not been recognized as particularly influential

qas.question: What is the general opinion of Whitehead in less philosophical schools?

plausible_answers.text: assertion that matter is an abstraction

qas.question: what is an example of Whitehead's ideas not being counter-intuitive?
What is an uncommon opinion of metaphysics?

plausible_answers.text: sheer difficulty and density of his prose

qas.question: Why do some people believe Whitehead's writings may have not restricted his influence?

context: Deleuze's and Latour's opinions, however, are minority ones, as <a0_0>Whitehead has <b4_0>not been recognized as particularly influential<b4_0/> within the most dominant philosophical schools<a0_0/>. It is impossible to say exactly why Whitehead's influence has not been more widespread, but it may be partly due to his metaphysical ideas seeming somewhat counter-intuitive (such as <a1_0>his <b5_0>assertion that matter is an abstraction<b5_0/><a1_0/>), or his inclusion of theistic elements in his philosophy, or the <a2_0>perception of <b6_0>metaphysics itself as passé<b6_0/><a2_0/>, or simply <a3_0>the <b7_0>sheer difficulty and density of his prose<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
